questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Timothy 1:1-16 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between Paul's past as a blasphemer and his current mercy.
tips: Notice the phrase 'Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners' (v.15) appears with Paul's humility
Pay attention to the repeated phrase 'the law' in verses 8-9
The phrase 'wage the good warfare' (v.18) shows the urgency of the call

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is warned, WHAT is forbidden, WHERE it occurs, and WHY Paul gives this warning.
tips: Include Paul's past as a blasphemer and persecutor (v.13)
Note the warning against false teachers who teach different doctrines (v.3-4)
Describe the law being for the lawless (v.8-9)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Paul's humility (v.13), the law for the lawless (v.8-9), or the call to wage the good warfare (v.18)?
tips: Paul's admission of being a blasphemer and persecutor shows his humility and the grace of God
The law being for the lawless (v.8-9) is a practical application that helps us understand the law in our current situation
The call to wage the good warfare (v.18) is an active call to stand firm in faith

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to Timothy about the danger of false teachers and the need for sound doctrine?
tips: Paul's purpose is to warn Timothy about the false teachers who lead away from the true gospel
The Christ connection (v.15) shows that the gospel is for sinners and that Paul, as a sinner, was saved by grace
This passage is a call to maintain the purity of the gospel in the church at Ephesus

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The definition of false teachers, the application of the law, or the call to wage the good warfare?
tips: False teachers: In the context of Ephesus, these might be Jewish teachers or Gnostic teachers who were active in the early church
The law for the lawless: The Mosaic law was given for the lawless (those without faith) but Paul says it is good when used lawfully
Waging the good warfare: This requires active faith and a good conscience, which can be challenging in today's world

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Paul warns against false teachers and calls for the good warfare. What specific area of your life requires you to be vigilant against false teachings this week?
tips: Identify one false teaching that might be influencing you (e.g., from social media, friends, or cultural trends)
Pray for wisdom to discern the truth and to hold fast to sound doctrine
Take a step of obedience by sharing the gospel with someone who might be influenced by false teachers

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His mercy in saving Paul and for the warning against false teachers. Ask for the courage to wage the good warfare.
tips: Thank God that He saved Paul (v.13) and that He calls us to be vigilant
Pray for the strength to resist false teachers and to hold fast to sound doctrine
Ask God to help us wage the good warfare with faith and a good conscience

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Timothy 3:1-16 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the qualifications for overseers (vv. 1-7) and deacons (vv. 8-13).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'household' (v. 4, v. 15) as a unifying theme
Pay attention to the phrase 'above reproach' (v. 2) appearing three times in the chapter
Listen for the emotional shift from demanding standards to hopeful conclusion in v. 16

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being qualified, WHAT they must do, WHERE this leadership happens, and WHY Paul emphasizes these standards.
tips: Include the household management requirement for overseers (v. 4)
Note the testing process for deacons before service (v. 10)
Describe the church as 'the household of God' (v. 15)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the 'household of God' metaphor (v. 15), the requirement for overseers to be 'above reproach' (v. 2), or the mystery of godliness (v. 16).
tips: The phrase 'household of God' (v. 15) connects church leadership to family life in a way that feels deeply personal
The 'above reproach' standard (v. 2) creates a high bar that emphasizes integrity over popularity
The mystery of godliness (v. 16) beautifully ties the entire passage to Christ's work in the gospel

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to Timothy about the qualifications for church leadership?
tips: Paul is ensuring leaders reflect Christ's character (v. 16) through rigorous standards
The qualifications prevent the church from being led by those who would harm the community
This passage establishes that leadership in the church must be rooted in Christ's example

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The household management requirement for overseers? The testing process for deacons? The concept of 'mystery of godliness'?
tips: 'Household of God' (v. 15) refers to the church as a family unit, not just a building
'Above reproach' (v. 2) requires consistent moral integrity that can be hard to measure in practice
The 'mystery of godliness' (v. 16) is a theological concept that the early church understood as Christ's full revelation of God

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the requirement for overseers to manage their own households (v. 4) to your life this week?
tips: Reflect on how your home life reflects your readiness to lead the church
Consider if you are being a good steward of your family before you can lead others
Practice 'managing your household well' by setting clear boundaries and priorities

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the qualifications He sets for church leadership. Ask for wisdom to lead your family and church in faithfulness.
tips: Thank God for the example of Christ who is the ultimate leader and provides the qualifications
Pray for courage to be 'above reproach' in your relationships
Ask God to strengthen your ability to manage your household well and serve others

chapters.chapterTitle: A Good Servant of Christ Jesus

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Timothy 4:1-16 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'the Spirit' and the phrase 'train yourself for godliness'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the Spirit' (v.1, v.3, v.5)
Pay attention to the phrase 'train yourself for godliness' (v.7) which is a key command
Note the emotional tone of urgency in verses 9-11 about false teachings

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (Paul) is communicating WHAT (the dangers of false teachings and the call to godliness) to WHO (Timothy) WHERE (the church) WHY (to prevent the spread of false teachings and to ensure Timothy's ministry is effective).
tips: Paul's warning about false teachings in later times (v.1-3)
Timothy's role as a servant to train others in the faith (v.10-12)
The call to persist in teaching and godliness (v.13-16)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the warning about false teachings (v.1-3), the command to 'train yourself for godliness' (v.7), or the emphasis on hope in Christ (v.13)?
tips: The phrase 'the Spirit expressly says' (v.1) shows divine authority for the warning
The contrast between God's good creation and the false teachings (v.3-4) is profound
The promise that godliness holds promise for the present life and the life to come (v.8) is a powerful motivator

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to Timothy through this passage?
tips: Paul's primary aim is to ensure Timothy's ministry remains faithful in the face of emerging false teachings
The passage emphasizes that true godliness is the foundation for effective ministry and that Timothy must be a living example of Christ-like character
This passage also serves as a reminder that the church's health depends on the faithful teaching of the Word

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The definition of 'false teachings', the cultural context of abstinence from foods, and the concept of 'the Spirit expressly says'?
tips: 'False teachings' in 1 Timothy 4:1-3 refers to teachings that depart from the faith, which in the context of the early church meant heresies and false gospels
The phrase 'abstinence from foods that God created' (v.3) relates to the early church's debates on dietary laws, particularly in light of the New Testament
'The Spirit expressly says' (v.1) is a direct reference to the Holy Spirit's guidance, which in the early church was understood as the divine revelation

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Timothy is called to train others in godliness. What specific area of godliness can you focus on this week to become a better example?
tips: Choose one area: such as teaching others the importance of thanksgiving in receiving God's provision
Practice by sharing a brief word of encouragement with someone this week
Reflect on how your actions (speech, conduct, love) can be an example to others

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the promise of Christ as the Savior and ask for the strength to be a good servant in the face of false teachings.
tips: Thank God for the promise of Christ as the Savior
Ask for courage to resist false teachings and to stay committed to godliness
Pray for the church to be united in the truth and for Timothy to be a faithful example

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Timothy 6:1-21 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between false teachers and the call for contentment.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'contentment' (v. 8, 9, 12) and 'flee' (v. 11, 12)
Pay attention to the phrase 'Godliness with contentment is great gain' (v. 8)
The emotional tone shifts from warning (v. 3-4) to encouragement (v. 11-12)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Paul) is addressing, WHAT (the warning against false teachers and the call for contentment), WHERE (the church in the context of false teachings), and WHY (to avoid the love of money and maintain godliness).
tips: Include the false teachers who teach a different doctrine (v. 3-4)
Note the command for the rich to flee the love of money (v. 9-10)
Describe the call to pursue righteousness and godliness (v. 11-12)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the warning about false teachers (v. 3-4), the call to contentment (v. 8), or the command for the rich to flee (v. 9-10)?
tips: The phrase 'Godliness with contentment is great gain' (v. 8) is a concise and profound statement that captures the essence of the passage
The contrast between the love of money (v. 10) and the call to pursue righteousness (v. 11) highlights the tension in modern life
The declaration that 'God is the only one who has immortality' (v. 16) is a powerful reminder of eternal security

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to Timothy through this passage?
tips: Paul is warning Timothy about false teachers who have abandoned the true teaching of Christ
He emphasizes that true contentment comes from God, not from material wealth
This passage is a call to a life of spiritual discipline and focus on eternal things, especially in the face of false teachings and the temptation of wealth

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The definition of false teachers (v. 3-4), the nature of contentment (v. 8), or the call for the rich to flee (v. 9-10)?
tips: The term 'false teachers' (v. 3) refers to those who have not been taught by Paul and have introduced doctrines not in line with the true teaching of Christ
Contentment (v. 8) is not about being satisfied with poverty but about being content with what God provides without the need for more
The command for the rich to 'flee' (v. 11) is not a call to give up wealth but to avoid the love of money and set their hopes on God

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice godliness with contentment this week?
tips: Identify one area where you are seeking more than what God provides (e.g., material wealth, status) and surrender it to God
Practice gratitude by listing three things you are content with, even if they are simple
Share your contentment with a friend or family member to reinforce the lesson

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the church and your own life regarding false teachers and contentment.
tips: Thank God for the truth that contentment is great gain and that He provides for us
Ask for the strength to flee the love of money and to set our hopes on God
Pray for Timothy and the church to be protected from false teachers and to pursue righteousness
